{"step_by_step_thinking": "The question asks about dense irregular connective tissue. The relevant documents are the ones that describe unusual cases or conditions. Ringed enamel hyperplasia is a condition of tooth enamel, which doesn't involve connective tissue. The case report on firearm-injury and the one on spinal cord compression by a rheumatoid nodule don't mention connective tissue either. However, the case report on wood as an organic foreign body in bone mentions 'epiphyseal cartilage', which is part of a joint or bone. Dense irregular connective tissue is often found in the supporting structures of joints and bones, such as tendons and ligaments.", "answer_choice": "D"}
